top_comment.text:
Where do we have an absolute autonomy of the market? How can a completely 
unregulated market be responsible for anything when no such market even 
exists anywhere? And please don't say Somalia, because Somalia became a 
disaster while under state control, and then its state collapsed. Citing 
Somalia as a failure of freedom is like citing a former smoker with cancer 
as an example of why it's bad to quit smoking.

Also, even if I were to grant you Somalia, that wouldn't explain how "an 
absolute autonomy of the market" is responsible for anything going on in 
the US, or any of the other parts of the world where people claim that 
wealth inequality is a problem; since we don't have "an absolute autonomy 
of the market" in those places. But then, I guess I shouldn't be surprised 
that the Pope would think something that doesn't exist should take credit 
for the way the world is.

Also, why is wealth inequality bad? The more equal everyone is in wealth, 
the worse off everyone is. Suppose that everyone had $1 million. Everyone 
would be as equal as they could possibly be, but we'd all be poor, because 
$1 million would be worth next to nothing due to the fact that everyone had 
it.

Lastly, I have a question for anyone who is a theist who also claims to 
believe that the well off should help those in need. How do rationalize the 
fact that God supposedly has unlimited power and is capable of doing 
anything he wants, yet people who need help still exist? If it's moral for 
the well off to help those in need, shouldn't God help everyone in need? 
God's resources are unlimited. No one is more well off than God. He's the 
ultimate rich guy. He could end poverty, feed all the hungry, cure every 
disease, and end all suffering, and it wouldn't cost him anything, because, 
as I said, his resources are unlimited. So why doesn't he do that? And, if 
it's immoral for the well off to refuse to help those in need, then 
wouldn't that make God immoral?﻿

Catholicism envisions a Kingdom of God that is eternal and not of this 
world, and there your first-year philosophy student logic falls apart. The 
temporal suffering that we experience, each in his or her own degree, and 
obviously not meted out equally, is infinitesimal when compared to the 
infinite reward the faithful are promised in heaven. You're absolutely 
right that God is the ultimate rich guy, Jesus says so quite candidly: "In 
my father's house there are many mansions." John 14:2. He goes on to say 
that he is going to prepare a place for us and receive us there - it's a 
promise, a covenant. But he also warns that we have a choice of whether we 
store our treasure in heaven or on earth (one might quibble here that some

afterlife, which changes the calculus considerably. If that's the case, you 
might consider the Jewish response, that we can through acts of 
righteousness bring ourselves closer to achieving God's original vision for 
the world in our lifetime. In Hebrew it's called tikkun olam, healing the 
world. A really beautiful concept.

top_comment.text:
As an anti-theist *a la* Hitchens, I have to say that this pope is 
surprising me as well. I would rather see the Catholic church dismantled, 
as well as other religious organizations, but if he's fighting the good 
fight and concentrating on important humanist issues, then I have much, 
much, less of a problem with him.

For those who are commenting that he should be doing something about these 
things: I think that he actually is. I've actually read the paper released 
a few days ago (and yes, it is very long), and he calls for massive changes 
in the church, including changes on issues which were previously dogmatic 
and never thought to be changed. He has called a special council for 
discussion and reform, and I believe he actually means it. Of course, we'll 
have to see what he does in the future, but we all know that changes in the 
church take epochs in general. As it is, he's as much of a revolutionary as 
we'll ever see in the church today and I believe he truly means what he 
says. Even though he could technically rule by fiat and change everything 
overnight, he knows full well that it wouldn't simply be accepted and would 
form another rift. If he's going to change the church, a rift isn't going 
to change anything but harden the stance of those dissenters and will 
accomplish nothing.

No, I think he's doing something wise: he's trying to change the 
conversation and forcing people to discuss the issues which are important, 
and trying to get them to see the humanist side which he apparently truly 
believes in. And if he's able to get a consensus, then change will follow.

So I'm in the wait and see mode. I do, however, have high hopes for this 
pope. He may not live long enough to see all the changes which he wishes to 
enact, but he appears to be setting the tone, pace, and discussion for 
years to come. Perhaps that is his ultimate goal: to change the entire tone 
for the long run so that the next pope will have no choice but to go along 
with it, and future popes thereafter.

By the way, for those who point out that the vatican has been accused 
several times of money laundering and close ties with the mafia, this new 
pope has already angered many in the vatican by lashing out against this 
and saying that there will be no more of that. So much so that a few 
articles have been written about how the mafia has found itself in a very 
bad spot all of a sudden with what lies ahead in their financial stakes 
within the vatican. He appears to be ready to take that corruption on as 
well and, some think, could be risking his life in doing so. It's not a 
completely idle threat, so I believe that he is truly genuine in his 
humanist activism.

We'll see what he brings in the future. But I don't recall reading about 
such an active pope since the middle ages, nor do I recall reading about 
such a pope who has made such provocatively humanist statements in the 
entire history of the church.﻿

We are not a breed of Ape. They are cool though, maybe the Sasquatch is the

part of a wave of resistance throughout the colonies, had its origin in 
Parliament's effort to rescue the financially weakened East India Company 
so as to continue benefiting from the company's valuable position in India. 
The Tea Act (May 10, 1773) adjusted import duties in such a way that the 
company could undersell even smugglers in the colonies. The company 
selected consignees in Boston, New York, Charleston, and Philadelphia, and 
500,000 pounds of tea were shipped across the Atlantic in September.
Under pressure from Patriot groups, the consignees in Charleston, New York, 
and Philadelphia refused to accept the tea shipments, but in Boston, the 
chosen merchants (including two of Governor Thomas Hutchinson's sons as 
well as his nephew) refused to concede. The first tea ship, Dartmouth, 
reached Boston November 27, and two more arrived shortly thereafter. 
Meanwhile, several mass meetings were held to demand that the tea be sent 
back to England with the duty unpaid. Tension mounted as Patriot groups led 
by Samuel Adams tried to persuade the consignees and then the governor to 
accept this approach. On December 16, a large meeting at the Old South 
Church was told of Hutchinson's final refusal. About midnight, watched by a 
large crowd, Adams and a small group of Sons of Liberty disguised as Mohawk 
Indians boarded the ships and jettisoned the tea. To Parliament, the Boston 
Tea Party confirmed Massachusetts's role as the core of resistance to 
legitimate British rule. The Coercive Acts of 1774 were intended to punish 
the colony in general and Boston in particular, both for the Tea Party and 
for the pattern of resistance it exemplified."
The Reader's Companion to American History. Eric Foner and John A. Garraty.
You are either British or a huge fan of colonialism.

comments.text:
+think about it - Thanks for sharing your thoughts too! I see we do have a 
difference of opinion but I try to be fair to your opinion as well. The 
Communism you're describing is the policy of countries controlled by 
Communist Parties. Their particular ideology was usually Stalinism or 
Maoism (different flavors of Bolshevism). They believed the State could be 
used to redistribute Capitalism into Socialism and then into Communism. 
That was Lenin's interpretation of Marx's "dictatorship of the proletariat" 
maxim (of course evidence shows their interpretation was likely WAY 
different from Marx's). They never proclaimed to have achieved communism, 
they claimed to be in transition towards it. Some other communist 
ideologies, like anarcho-communism, propose that the State can never create 
a communistic society and that it can only be reached with the abolition of 
the state along with capitalism.

Anarchism itself is compatible with communism but it is also compatible 
with other economic systems like socialism, collectivism, individualism and 
Georgism. Some argue it's compatible with capitalism 
("anarcho-capitalism"), but I largely disagree with the latter. I think 
it's only compatible with capitalism if capitalism gets rid of most of its 
involuntary hierarchy and free from the influence of monopolies, 
oligopolies and cartels, and people are free to renegotiate or leave 
contracts. Basically it would have to change to the point of becoming very 
similar to Individualist Anarchism (which is an anarchistic flavor of 
Market Socialism), it would barely be capitalism anymore. 

Personally I'm a Libertarian Socialist and I tend to be non-partisan 
towards different varieties of socialism and communism. I like your idea 
about how wealth need not be solely classified as capital or monetary 
resources. I think as economies and societies become more advanced in the 
future expanding the definition of "wealth" will become very important, 
even vital. Thanks for sharing your viewpoints with me.
comments.author: A86

comments.text:
+A86 OK - I see we have a fundamental difference of opinion and it has 
certainly been interesting being exposed to yours and I will consider it 
along with what else I have read/learnt/discussed. (By the way I had some 
typos up there from an erroneous cut and paste)

My understanding was, whilst both systems (communism and anarchy) espouse 
public/common ownership, that communism used a more structured method of 
distribution (the state) as opposed to a voluntary method (anarchy). 

It may well be I am talking about communism in practice rather than early 
marxist philosophy. 

I would also point out that communism in practice (I live in a communist 
country) generally has larger bureaucracies and more government/state 
involvement as opposed to the anarchistic ideal where government/ the state 
- get out of the way!

I am a socialist, I believe in social responsibility and a far more 
equitable distribution of wealth (though I have a slight issue with the 
term wealth as it is perceived in a narrow way - it should include health, 
knowledge, education, opportunities etc). I think Pope Francis is saying 
some great things - wish I had the answers to the questions he raises - I 
don't (if only).

comments.text:
+think about it - Public ownership is not a State. By your logic 
international waters and air are owned by a State since they're commonly 
owned. A State is when an institution given special powers and a monopoly 
of force is given authority over an area. Usually operated by a small cadre 
- an elite group.

"is more about the self government"

Communism espouses the same thing as a goal. Hence why it pushes for the 
end of the State. In a stateless society society would need to be 
self-governed. 

"unless an anarchistic stat had 100% voluntary submission to community 
distribution"

If something is owned by the public how would an individual take ownership 
of it? They'd need to use force. Community distribution is the natural 
order of things until individuals or groups start using force to 
redistribute ownership of some (or all) of the resources to themselves and 
then use their ownership or monopoly to distribute their way. Community 
distribution isn't really involuntary unless it involves distributing your 
personal possessions.
comments.author: A86

comments.text:
+A86 No - Communism (even at its most basic) is not stateless - in fact it 
relies on common ownership (not the more ephemeral - it belongs to it 
naturally belongs to us all). It relies on the fact that all property is 
owned by the community and each person contributes and receives according 
to their ability and needs.
Anarchism is by definition stateless (as you say) - one relies on a central 
community that distributes wealth/commodity as required/earned - anarchism 
is more about the self government and voluntary involvement - unless an 
anarchistic stat had 100% voluntary submission to community distribution 
then the communist idiom could not operate

comments.text:
+think about it - No. Technically a communistic society is a stateless, 
classless, post-monetary society where the means of production (factories, 
farms, workplaces, etc.) are owned in common by society. Similar to public 
parks or international waters. Fits pretty well with anarchism - a 
stateless, classless society with minimal hierarchy. What people generally 
call "Communism" is actually Bolshevism or Stalinism. The policy of the 
Communist Parties of the Soviet Union and China and their allies. 
Bolshevism is (self-admittedly, from Vlad Lenin's own mouth) actually a 
form of "State Capitalism" (where the government acts as a single monopoly 
capitalist owning all means of production and determining wages and 
distribution of produce). He claimed their society was a "transitional" 
stage between Capitalism and Socialism. Bolsheviks (and Marxists in 
general) believe you have to gradually transition from Capitalism to 
Socialism to Communism. Different Marxists disagree on how. 
Anarcho-communists believe in a direct transition from Capitalism to 
Communism with no state-guidance or takeover. They believe the State is 
another instrument of class society like private monopoly of capital/means 
of production (Capitalism).
